page.title: 14THE CHURCH IN OFFLEY
page.content: Edward III gave a grant for a church to be built at Offley. Legend suggests that King Offa was connected with a church on this site but the evidence cannot be validated; tiles once thought to have Offa written on them were in fact to commemorate one Ossa, written in the old English style. The south porch is early English. The font is a beautiful example of Totternhoe stone carved in the late 14th century; unlike other fonts in the area this one is undamaged. The chancel was re-designed by the Salusbury family in 1777 and holds a monument by Nollekens to Sir Thomas Salusbury. The crenell- ations have caused the chancel to be in need of structural support. The tower contains a peel of six bells. Unfortunately, the church is not well attended and the priest-in-charge lives in another village.
